bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, September 16, 1937

div1.p: Andrus writes that Truby was not in Cuba at the time Andrus alleges Reed proposed to inoculate himself.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, September 16, 1937
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
9-16-37.
General Albert E. Truby,
145 Laurel St.,
San Francisco, Cal.
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of the eighth. It is an addi-
tional proof that there are some mighty nice people in this
old world. I am grateful that it has been my privilege
to have known so many of them.

Am disappointed that you were away from Columbia Barracks
at the time Major Reed had decided to order his innoculation.
Lieut. Carroll was so fearful of the probable outcome that I
felt very certain he had appealed to you. There is no
doubt in my mind that he would have done so had you been
available.

It probably makes no difference as I have not heard from any-
one with reference to my letter to the Secretary of War.

Thank you for the print of the group photograph. I have
one of them and have had it resurrected in an effort to iden-
tify number 40. It is amazing that you were able to name
so many after the years since it was taken.
No. 15 is Private Morris. Do not remember his full name.

No. 27 is NOT Clyde L West but Fred G. West. Am certain
of this. Fred G. was the detachment barber. Clyde L.
lives at Riverdale, Md. and visited me several times while I
was in Walter Reed Hospital.
No. 39 is Private Frank M. Dawley. (Am certain,)

No. 40 Do not think this is Weatherwalks. It is exasper-
ating that I cannot recall his name as I remember him.
It may come to me later. If so, will advise you.
With kindest regards and best wishes,
